title: McKinsey RetailPro: Declining Department Store Profits
problemStatement: Your client is RetailPro Inc., a large department store chain with 200 stores across North America. Despite stable overall revenue for the past three years, their net profit margin has declined from 8% to 4%. The CEO is concerned and has asked McKinsey to identify the root causes of the profit decline and recommend strategies to restore profitability.

costStructure.sg&a: Increased by 8% over 3 years (driven by marketing and store labor)

competitorInfo.impact: Increased price pressure, especially in Apparel

contextForTheCase.industryBackground: Traditional department stores face significant pressure from online competition and changing consumer preferences. Many are struggling to maintain margins.
contextForTheCase.clientBackground: RetailPro is known for its mid-range offerings and strong store presence but has been slow to adapt its e-commerce strategy. They recently invested heavily in store renovations.
keyConsiderations: Impact of product mix on overall margin

interviewerHints.frameworkExpectations: A profitability framework (Profit = Revenue - Costs) is essential. Break down revenue (price x volume) and costs (COGS, SG&A) further. Consider segmenting by product category or channel.
keyInsights: The sharp decline in Apparel margins is likely a major driver.
Both COGS and SG&A increases need investigation.
Competitive pressure is impacting pricing power.
strongAnswerElements: Hypothesis-driven investigation into cost increases and margin declines.
Consideration of both internal factors (product mix, operations) and external factors (competition).
Actionable recommendations targeting specific levers (e.g., renegotiate supplier costs, optimize marketing spend, improve online channel).
